awd_titl_txt: Ultrafast spectroscopy beyond the diffraction limit: elucidating charge and lattice interactions with individual grain boundaries
awd_abstract_narration:
Fundamental understanding and effective engineering of electrical and thermal transport processes in materials is important, as the efficiency of our energy infrastructure and the reliable performance of electronic devices, the transportation and the power systems are significantly affected by these processes. Polycrystalline materials consisting of microscale crystal grains separated by grain boundaries are an important class of materials widely used in thin-film solar cells, high-performance thermoelectric modules and electronic and photonic devices.  How electrical and thermal energy is transferred across the grain boundaries strongly impacts the macroscopic transport properties of polycrystalline materials and device performance. Currently, a detailed understanding of these microscopic processes is still lacking. The overarching goal of this project is to develop theoretical and experimental techniques to elucidate local energy transport processes across individual grain boundaries. Specifically, the research team will use ultrafast optical and electron spectroscopies to examine how these processes are affected by the morphology, structure and disorder of the grain boundaries. This project supports educational activities to advocate renewable energy technologies to K-12 and undergraduate students through hands-on class projects and short classes. To promote diversity in the renewable energy workforce, the research team also provides research opportunities to high school and undergraduate researchers from underrepresented minority communities.  

A thorough understanding of the structure-property relationship of functional materials with complex microstructures has been a longstanding goal for modern materials science. Grain boundaries are among the most common microstructures with significant influence on the macroscopic properties. Despite the paramount importance of grain boundaries in functional materials, most previous studies have focused on the average effect of a macroscopic ensemble of grain boundaries and/or under static and equilibrium conditions. This project aims to address this challenge by combining state-of-the-art first-principles simulations with ultrafast optical and electron spectroscopy with high spatial-temporal resolutions. Specifically, the research team will examine individual grain boundaries in multicrystalline silicon, polycrystalline perovskites and nanostructured thermoelectric materials regarding their local interactions with electrons and phonons and their impact on the macroscopic electrical and thermoelectric transport properties. This project provides a systematic understanding of how individual grain boundaries affect local electron and phonon transport properties, especially under dynamic and non-equilibrium conditions. This knowledge can enable transformative opportunities to build functional materials with a bottom-up approach, "one grain at a time".

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the award period, we have made significant progress developing both the experimental implementation and the theoretical understanding of the scanning ultrafast electron microscope (SUEM) technique and applying SUEM to study microscopic energy transport across grain boundaries and interfaces in a variety of materials. Our achievements are documented in 6 peer-reviewed journal publications (2 under review) and 3 conference presentations (one invited talk). 

One major achievement is that we accomplished the development of SUEM at UCSB, a one-of-a-kind scientific instrumentation that can probe microscopic energy transport processes with combined nanometer spatial resolution and femtosecond time resolution. The SUEM setup at UCSB is the only operating one in a US university at this moment. The UCSB setup features state-of-the-art improvement including a high signal-to-noise ratio, multi-modal detection and compressed optical pump size. We conducted a benchmark study to quantify the SUEM image contrast and correlate it with the surface photovoltage effect (SPV) in doped semiconductors. Through a systematic measurement of the secondary electron yield from silicon surface as influenced by a modulated optical pump, we established that the SPV effect is a major contributing factor to the SUEM contrasts. This finding is a cornerstone for quantitative interpretation of SUEM images in future applicatios. In another benchmarking study, we collaborated with the Sandia National Lab to examine the SPV effect at an Si/SiO2 interface using SUEM, and further demonstrated that the SPV effect can not only impact secondary electron yield at the sample surface but also at buried interfaces. 

Given the short history of SUEM, a quantitative understanding of its image contrast remains elusive. During the award period, we developed a unique simulation technique combining Monte Carlo simulation of high-energy electron transport in solids with time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) to capture the effect of photoexcitation on secondary electron emission from semiconductors, which is the basis for the SUEM image contrast. Specifically, we studied the contribution from three potential factors: (i) the presence of thermalized photocarriers in the bulk of the sample; (ii) the surface photovoltage effect on the sample surface; (iii) the hot photocarrier distribution immediately after photoexcitation before thermalization. We find that the thermalized photocarriers play a negligible role in changing the secondary electron yield, due to the fact that the concentration of photogenerated charge carriers is orders-of-magnitude smaller than that of all valence electrons, which is consistent with an analytical model. Instead, we find that both the SPV effect and the hot photocarrier effect have a major impact on the secondary electron yield but they occur at different timescales. Our simulation generates a clear physical picture to understand the formation of SUEM image contrasts and provides a solid basis for quantitatively interpreting SUEM image constrasts in its future applications.

In addition to instrumentation development (both experimentally and theoretically) of the SUEM technique, we have applied SUEM to image transport of microscopic energy transport in microstructured materials with combined high spatial and temporal resolutions. As a first example, we studied photocarrier transport in silicon under strong excitation conditions. We found that, when the optical pump fluence is high (close to the damage threshold of silicon), the high density of electrons and holes undergo spatial oscillations at THz frequency. This behavior creates a distinct feature of wave-like contrast in the SUEM time-resolved images. This intriguing fundamental observation may also lead to new applications in THz generation and detection. We then applied SUEM to understand the photo-response of materials with more complicated microstructures. For example, we used SUEM to image the time- and space-resolved photo-response of a semiconducting polymer P3HT, which is a mainstream material for OLED and OPV applications. We observed ring-shaped contrasts on the time scale of a few hundred picoseconds. We attributed this response to the photo-induced strain in P3HT and the resultant modulation of its electronic structure. This finding is highly relevant to strain engineering of organic electronic devices. We also studied photo-induced ion transport in polycrystalline organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites with micrometer scale grains and grain boundaries. For this study, we further utilized the multi-modal detection capability of SUEM by combining the in situ laser exposure with secondary electron imaging, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and cathodoluminescence. We observed that the controlled exposure to laser light led to long-range contrast in the secondary electron images which can be correlated to a change in the X-ray photon counts corresponding to different elements in the material. The change in the X-ray signal reflects the photo-driven motion of various ions along both the in-plane and the cross-plane directions. We further mapped the ion-migration to the change in the optoelectronic properties using in situ cathodoluminescence measurement. This systematic study provides a panoramic view of how ion-migration in hybrid perovskites, largely facilitated by the presence of grain boundaries, affects the stability and the performance of perovskite-based solar cells and photodetectors.
